reviewText: I think David Gilmour is a real talent and this performance bears that out. Unfortunately whoever mastered thisDVD couldn't be bothered to keep the audio levels constant. It seems every time the performance starts to take offthe audio level drops down considerably and takes the energy out of the songs. It ruins a stellar performance.It sounds like a monkey is handling on the faders in the mix. Though that's not fair to monkeys. It's a real shame.

reviewText: Awesome concert. DVD well produced. If you haven't bought a David Gilmour DVD, this is the one to buy. Echoes live in this concert has to be one of the best live songs I've ever heard performed. The tempo shifts throughout that build to an explosive crescendo left me speechless. If you buy this DVD for just that experience alone it's worth it. On An Island in it's entirety was very well done, studio like quality from a live concert is rarely achieved, but Gilmour manages to do it yet again.  Buy this DVD, you won't be disappointed.
summary: Gilmour, like fine wine, gets better with age

reviewText: While this performance is top-notch and spit polished like the most beautiful pair of shoes you've ever seen, this lavish production lacks the one ingredient that maketh a great rock concert. It has no spontaneity to it at all. You can tell that Gilmour's band is so well-rehearsed with each and every tune that you would be hard pressed to hear one bum note throughout the entire performance. But what matters here, is less the expertness and polished production, more the spontaneity and impromptu performance by a band which distinguishes itself from other bands. This concert is superlatively performed. But it lacks soul. Gilmour plays with passion but everything is so rehearsed that I wonder how much soul he's really generating when he knows exactly what note he's going to play at each and every moment!Overall, a great production. But it lacks spontaneity and dare I say it, the music, while melodious and sublime, could also put one to sleep with its lack of spontaneity.  It's just too well-rehearsed. And that my friends, is a valid criticism.

reviewText: In late May, 2006 David Gilmour performed at London's Royal Albert Hall in support of his On An Island CD. With him in the band were Pink Floyd's keyboardist Richard Wright, ex-Roxy Music guitarist Phil Manzanera, Guy Pratt on bass, Jon Carin on keyboards, Steve DiStanislao on drums and Dick Parry on saxophone.The show was divided into two distinct parts. The first half featured the complete On An Island album with three songs from Dark Side of the Moon. The On An Island material is perhaps Gilmour's best work in years and highlights include the title song, This Heaven, The Blue, Smile and Take a Breath. The band is joined by David Crosby and Graham Nash for On An Island and the Blue.The second set features much of the standard Pink Floyd catalogue. Beginning with Shine On You Crazy Diamond, Gilmour and the band work through Fat Old Sun, Coming Back to Life, High Hopes and Wish You Were Here. The highlight of the evening is a performance of the classic Echoes with full light show in effect. David Bowie joins in for Arnold Layne and Comfortably Numb.As mentioned before this is Gilmour's best material in ages. Gilmour is having fun on this tour and it shows. All in all this is one of the best concert DVD's of the year. A second disc of extras includes the not to be missed tour documentary Breaking Bread,Drinking Wine, extra footage from the Royal Albert Hall, two making of documentaries, some first performance footage of On An Island and more.  In total you get over five hours of material on these discs.This is a set not to be missed by the Gilmour or Pink Floyd fan and it is a good introduction to the catalogue for the curious.Do yourself a favor and get it.As a side note I experienced none of the skipping problems that have plagued earlier releases of this disc. Let's hope that that problem is finally solved so that the disc may be enjoyed to its fullest extent.
summary: One of the Best Concert DVD's of the Year
Title: N/A

reviewText: How so very sad that David Gilmour's ex-Pink Floyd bandmate Richard Wright is such a bright star on this wonderful DVD, and now we have lost Richard to a premature death on September 15th, two days ago. Richard and David were the musical creators in Pink Floyd ( Roger was the lyrical/artisical creator ), and together here on one last tour they recreate some great old Pink Floyd music. As others have said here already, their rendition of Echoes is worth the price of the whole dvd. Richard Wright plays his Hammond like he did back in the seventies. He is featured a lot more than he was on PULSE. David Gilmour is a class act as well as a brilliant guitarist. I'm so glad he asked Richard along on this tour. They always played well together; this great dvd recording is how I'll always remember David Gilmour and Richard Wright together. Rest in peace, Richard...
summary: Our last glimpse of the Late Great Richard Wright

reviewText: I hate to rate it like this but...Just got it yesterday and watched most of it.  Great floyd music as usual- sound is pretty good, but the video SUCKS!!!!!You would think the concert video people (CMG?) would learn how to film a concert like this for one in HD, and two how to figure out darker/ less light shots.  Since Floyd uses a lot of lighting/lasers, etc, you would think they would have this ready to go.  Apparently not.  The video is extremely grainy.  I have a projector that throws a 110" screen and it looks like hell on there.  Even Roger Waters video is much, much clearer.  I am mostly dissapointed because it looks like a great concert, but is ruined by sheety video.  These guys aint gonna be around forever, do you think we could get ONE decent DVD out of them (producers)?

reviewText: This Blu-ray isn't perfect. The flaws? A lot of smoke used in their show detracts from blu-ray perfect video quality.Wah. Nick Mason would have been nice to see. Boo-hoo. And it's rather bitter-sweet knowing this is my last really good look at Richard Wright before his death. RIP, Rick, we'll miss you.Those gripes aside, this is 6 hours of Gilmour/Pink Floyd bliss. As other reviewers have noted seeing Gilmour & Wright doing Echoes is worth the price of purchase all by itself. Same with Astronomy Domaine. I've always loved Gilmours guitar. 'Soaring' has always been the word I use to describe his wonderful skill. A 2.5 hour concert with 3.5 hours of extra songs, documentaries, etc.Well worth the price & I'll probably grab this blu-ray over the Pulse dvd when I need my Pink Floyd fix.

reviewText: I'm a pretty big Pink Floyd / David Gilmour fan, so I was excited to see this on blu-ray. I had just bought a new receiver with HDMI inputs, so I was definitely looking forward to listening to this in such high quality. I was not disappointed. The audio quality is superb. The video is mostly great... however at other times it suffers from film grain and some other artifacts from time to time. The menu system on the blu-ray is a bit annoying. You have to wait for an animation before you can see the next screen or where you're navigating to. There is no pop-up menu that you can use while viewing the concert. This was a bit troublesome when trying to select specific songs or changing audio options. Other than that, the concert is beautifully done. I would recommend this to any Pink Floyd / David Gilmour fan.

reviewText: Another reviewer mentioned that having Echoes here was worth the price of the DVD alone. I would agree, and add that having Wots..Uh the Deal also makes this worth the bucks. Too many of these songs he has done before ad infinitum (do we really need another take on Coming Back to Life or High Hopes??), but having this great track from my favorite Floyd album "Obscured By Clouds", is just great! Since that album is probably their least known (and certainly most underrated, in my book), it may serve to convince people to go back and see where this beautiful song came from. Other than that, great picture and sound, and a ton of extras (not to mention what must be 3 1/2 hours of music), makes this one a must-have! And I only paid $11.99!!!

reviewText: Literally worth five times the price and an equal in it's own way to PULSE, with intimacy and a freer feel offsetting the more minimal lighting (although enormously impressive in its own right.)As the other reviewers have given an accurate overview I'll just mention one cut, that being "Comfortably Numb," which you and I know every second of by heart, it's in our blood.This performance features David Bowie sharing lead vocals. Now the idea of anyone but Mr. Gilmour taking over vocals on this song is enough to make my hair catch on fire, but THIS WORKS. It actually becomes a Bowie song while remaining a Floyd epoch. It's thrilling, it's almost dreamlike to watch a singer of equal caliber and credibility to Mr. Gilmour share this song and to take it's inherent drama and mystery to another level entirely.The DVD also points out what a superb disc "On An Island" is, sadly overlooked by too many Floyd fans for not being heavy enough (man.)And it's in high def - you can almost reach out and shake Rick Wright's hand.Extras are top flight, set is an incredible bargain and you'll have trouble turning it off and going to bed. Mr. Gilmour once again proves that he's in a class all by himself, a category of artist of which there is only one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: David Gilmour: Remember That Night - Live from the Royal Albert HallShort of being there, I can't imagine a better experience than I had with this DVD. Most live performances are a disappointment compared to studio recordings. This performance was not a disappointment! David Gilmour was in top form vocally and instrumentally. His guitar playing was searing and scintillating. He plays with more depth than anybody else. The addition of D. Crosby and G. Nash on some of the vocals elevated them beyond anything I have heard from Pink Floyd and that is hard to do. Richard Wright was prominent throughout and the other musicians were outstanding in every way. He performed "On an Island" plus many other tunes from earlier incarnations. I was a little disappointed in the previous live David Gilmour DVD I purchased but this one washed away any pangs I had. I don't have any live Pink Floyd DVDs so I can't compare this with any of those but I don't think I need to buy any now that I have this one. The light show was effective considering the concert hall. I can only advise you to spin this disk, dim the lights and let the outside in.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Buyer beware, amazon states that this DVD comes with the audio option "PCM Stereo Sound (48kHz/24bit)," which is lossless audio. This audio option, however, is what you get with the Bluray purchase, NOT the DVD. The DVD audio comes in AC3 (a Dolby product), which means that the audio stream is compressed to fit on the DVD, and is lossy (about the same as a high bitrate mp3). This might be no big deal for those using their stock TV speakers or earbuds, but for the audiophile with high-end equipment, you may notice the difference. If you're looking for lossless audio, do NOT buy the DVD. Go straight for the Bluray. This is an amazon error which should be corrected.
summary: 5 stars to David Gilmour, 1 star to Amazon...

reviewText: Well, initially I had a similar problem with this DVD that other reviewers were having since High Hopes and Coming Back To Life were skipping.  However, I exchanged it and so far there aren't any problems.  There must be a few defective DVDs out there.  I still watched the rest of the defective DVD of course.  Putting all that aside, this DVD is just incredible.  I agree with some of the other reviewers that it is better than Pulse (which I also love).  I feel in this DVD, you get a much clearer picture of what a brilliant guitarist and musician Gilmour is.  He is one of the best guitar players ever and you get plenty of close ups of him playing the guitar.  The focus is on Gilmour and the band playing the music instead of the visualization that exhibits Pulse.  Yes, there are many lighting effects but I feel that they don't distract the viewer from the brilliance of the performance.  The music is outstanding.  Great performances of Time, Breathe, Echoes, Shine On You Crazy Diamond, Wish You Were Here, Comfortably Numb, High Hopes, Coming Back To Life, Fat Old Sun, Arnold Layne, and On An Island in its entirety.  This DVD even has alternate versions of most of the songs plus a great version of "Wots..Uh the Deal."  While the album On An Island isn't as good as the best albums by Floyd, it is still a fantastic album and it is even better when Gilmour performs it live.  A definite plus for this DVD is the fact that Gilmour had Wright with him so you get half of Pink Floyd performing.  Those two have always been the best MUSICIANS in Pink Floyd anyway.  Waters is a very gifted songwriter but I wouldn't call him an outstanding bassist since Gilmour played many of the complicated bass parts for many Floyd songs.  Other highlights of this DVD include the tour documentary and the documentary of the making of On An Island.  You even get to witness Gilmour and Waters talking to each other and shaking hands although they both looked a little uncomfortable.  Mason even has a cameo apperance.  I also must add that you get to see the band play the intro to Time (instead of having to watch the clock video), you get to see the musicians play High Hopes (instead of having to watch that video like on the Pulse performance), and you get to see much more of Gilmour's second solo on Comfortably Numb.  I can't say enough about the brilliance of this DVD.  It has turned into one of my favorite DVDs in a matter of only a few days.  If your a fan of David Gilmour and Pink Floyd, you will love this DVD.  Also, for those of you who support Waters over Gilmour, remember that even though Waters was responsible for many of the Floyd's compositions, Gilmour (and Wright) was the best musician in the band and also the best singer.  He's the one who played all those brilliant guitar parts and he's the one who sang classics like Time (with Wright), Money, Breathe, Welcome to the Machine, Us and Them, Wish You Were Here, Echoes (with Wright), and many more.  Buy this DVD.  It is absolutely incredible.
summary: Could be the ultimate Floyd related DVD

reviewText: Gilmour shines - a magnificent performance captured as well as any could be.  The sound is perfectly recorded, mixed and encoded in Dolby 5.1.  Guest performers Graham Nash and David Crosby do yeoman's work backing Gilmour - but the standout guest performance is a surpassing rendition of Comfortably Numb with David Bowie.David's On an Island - a very personal project - is incorporated into the classic Floyd mix with care and it stands well with the early work.  Indeed, On an Island is contemporary "Floyd" and it is a work of art, too.Few people have the luck and funds to attend a performance that is this visually stunning and musically perfect.  The show runs 227 minutes!  I cannot think of many other performers or performances that can retain your attention for nearly four hours!This DVD is as close to the actual experience that most of us will ever have.  A real gem - shine on David Gilmour - you crazy diamond.

reviewText: I've been a Floyd fan since the early 70's, but not hardcore in any way. I liked Dark Side and a few major cuts from other albums, but I never went out of my way to own their vinyl... but NOW, I am truly impressed. Gilmour has created an incredibly beautiful double DVD set... with amazing tracks that yearn to be heard. The production of this DVD set was first rate, thoughtful and consice, masterful in strength and savory in number. Songs from the past sound 10x better than their originals without any loss of rhythm or tempo. This is a fantastic, complete and well orchestrated concert. Bravo and hats off to you and your crew DG!

reviewText: If there is at least ONE concert DVD in your collection it needs to be this one.  I mean with appearances by Bowie?  Crosby & Nash??? So I went to another store and finally got a good copy.The selection of songs are pretty good.  I'm happy with the mix. reviewText: David Gilmore is an excellent guitarist that does not rely on flashy playing to get his message across to the audiences that he plays for. David has his own immediatly recognizable playing style, that is often imitated by others. You could always recognize his immense influence on all of the Pink Floyd Records, from "The Dark Side of the Moon", to the very latest albums.This DVD is very valuble to me, because it shows David as a very down to earth performer, whom is always interested in releasing only the best product that is possible. This DVD has Pink Floyd songs,and songs from all of David's excellent solo albums, especially from "On An Island".You can't go wrong with this DVD if you want to see what life is like on tour now days. It is nice to see that David now takes his family on tour with him. Gone are the days of the wild parties, and groupies.

reviewerName: M. A. Whaley "remembering when music was good"
reviewText: 5 years ago I felt compelled to write a review of "In The Flesh" by Roger Waters, there were several anti-Roger/pro David reviews written at the time.  It's sad that I have to do the same again, in reverse.Brad King, it would be helpful if you had any idea what you were talking about.  As far as I can tell by the information provided, there are no "Roger Waters' songs" on this DVD.  There are Pink Floyd songs that Roger has co-writer credits, all of which David Gilmoue shared writing credit or songs David wrote himself, with the following exceptions:Speak To Me (Mason)Arnold Layne (Barrett)Wearing The Inside Out (Wright/Moore)The Great Gig In The Sky (Wright)David wrote the songs, he played and sang on the original recordings. Roger performs several of the songs live as well. They both have every right to play them now and until the day they die.  So Brad, please make sure you have the facts before you go on another rambling binge.  It just makes you look silly.That being said, I am really looking forward to this DVD being released, I'm sure it is a gem.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Yes, I like David and yes I think he's a fantastic guitarist.  Yes he owns the strat (that's "Fender Stratocaster" before you ask) and could probably make it dance across the stage by itself if he were so inclined.  And getting to hear "On an Island" in its entirity was wonderful.However, I can't help notice the pattern of the second set.  It seems the arrangements on some songs had bits cut out (most notably, "Shine On...") so that the guitar aspects are highlighted but the other parts are skipped.  "Echoes" (originally 18 minutes) is dragged out to well over 22 minutes and lacks the ferociousness of the original studio version (save for a great climax just before the last set of vocals).  Its great to see Richard Wright perform with David but on "Echoes" I do miss the wonderful organ during the build-up, replaced here with seemingly random tones and unorganized playing.  And during the song's close-out, where the two typically play off one another just before the ever-growing voices gently key in, David seems out of touch with Rick.  A better version of this is on the DVD in an Easter Egg where the last 6 minutes of "Echoes" is played during a rehursal with David on an Accustic guitar.  After I converted the tracks to mp3 files, I much rather hear this version than the ending of the live version.But enough knocking of "Echoes" (as I'm sure to get flamed for it!).  I did give this DVD 4-stars, however, because I did enjoy it and I do listen to it all the time on my iPod.  The sound and visual quality is supurb (despite getting speaker distortion from Guy Pratt's stand-up bass on no matter what sound system I listen to it on - probably my fault in that my settings are wrong).  I also enjoyed the accustical add-on to end of "High Hopes."  David Bowie was fantastic on "Arnold Layne" (see the single release by David Gilmour and David Bowie) and he added quite an interesting turn to "Comfortably Numb" (as Rick says in the interview, "He took Comfortably Numb and turned it into a David Bowie song... and it worked really well.").  Another great thing about this DVD is hearing a live performance of "Wearing the Inside Out."  Hearing that song performed live was great (still waiting to hear "Lost for Words" live, too, but oh well).It's a great track list and, with all the extras tracks and extra goodies(their are a lot), plus the Roger Waters run-in at a studio during the documentary, this DVD is a great buy and a must-have for Pink Floyd and/or David Gilmour fans.  I hope he does another!

reviewText: I have mixed feelings about this dvd/blu-ray.First off, I saw this tour when it hit the Toronto famous Massey Hall, that show was stunning and magnificent. A nearly spiritual happening. The interplay between David and Rick was something to behold, it is probably a feeling I will never experience again at a concert.Sadly this release failed to recapture the magic of that show. I'll cover the pros and cons of this release.Pros:1 The musicianship is superb2 OAI sounds way better live than it did on the overproduced studio version3 Rick Wright4 Deep cuts from the back catalog5 ECHOES!!!!!!6 The dvd sounds greatCons:1 Crosby and Nash detract and are a distraction from the flow of the show. Much better  without them2 David Bowie is horrible filling in for Roger Waters3 Video reproduction that fails to capture what the live show looked like4 Overproduced quick camera cuts and fading angles from the back of Royal Albert Hall are a distraction (although this is an unfortunate and common issue with many concert releases nowadays)5 CSN song "The Cost of Freedom" replaces the epic "Wots uh the Deal?" which was one of my favorite performances from the tour (Selling out to get CSN fans to buy this release?)6 Bowie singing for Waters on C Numb is not only horrible (point 2), but it takes away from one or Rick Wrights shining moments. Rick sang Rogers parts every night of this tour, except for the one that got released on DVD. WAS THE MONEY GRAB TO SELL THIS TO A FEW BOWIE FANS REALLY WORTH SELLING OUT YOUR FRIEND MR GILMOUR?7 In the first leg of the tour "speak to me, breathe, and time were the first songs of the second set and OAI was the first set. Not a huge deal but I liked it better that way.In conclusion this could have been a great release had they shown this tour in the way that 99% of the tour was. And that means NO Crosby, Nash, or Bowie. They could have included those tracks as extras.Instead we get extras of Rick Wright singing C Numb and an extra of Wots uh the Deal?. This stinks to high hell of a money grab to swing fans of CSN and Bowie to buy this who might not have otherwise purchased. Unfortunately you are selling out the artist integrity of the project in so doing.In the end this is worth buying. If nothing else Echoes alone is worth the price of admission! OAI also sounds way better live then studio.UPDATE:The Blu Ray is head and shoulders above the DVD. The audio of the Blu Ray is 10x better than the audio of the DVD. The picture is also a huge upgrade.That being said the above criticisms listed still apply. After viewing Pulse again it is hard to imagine that the same director put both of these films together.Die hard Floyd fans should have this, but, oh what could have been...

reviewText: I have been anxiously waiting for the release of this DVD for nearly a year (since I first learned there would BE a DVD). It was well worth the wait!Although several tracks (Shine On You Crazy Diamond, Comfortably Numb to name a few) appear on other Floyd/Gilmour DVD's, they are new and re-worked each time he plays them and the versions here are amazing (SOYCD with Crosby and Nash is fantastic; CN with Bowie gives Roger Waters' parts a new life). Also, the version of Time on this DVD is my favorite version of all.A song I never cared much for- Fat Old Sun- has new life here. As the song seems to be fading, Gilmour begins a guitar solo that is one of my faorite moments on the DVD.The 3 part harmony of Gilmour, Crosby and Nash on their song Find The Cost Of Freedom is brief but beautiful.The highlight of the DVD is Echoes in it's entirety (over 23 minutes!)! Long a favorite song from Floyd, I thought I would neer see it live. I had the joy of seeing it in person as well as having it on DVD now! This is probably the best version available.The enire album On An Island is played and the songs are even better live than they are on the studio album.Disk two contains seeral more tracks that didn't fit on disk one, including Wearing the Inside Out, in which the female chorus of the original album is sung by the men of the band with surprisingly good results. There is also a magnificent documentary of the tour that presents a band that likes each other having the time of their life. This tour was no job, but rather feels like a working vacation. There are other features as welll and at least one worthwhile surprise (Easter Egg). I highly recommend this DVD.  I have watched it repeatedly and am not in the slightest tired of it.The only negative thing is the lighting is at times so bright it washes out the performers. This I think is actually intentional on the part of the director (the same could be said of Pink Floyds' Pulse DVD). A minor complaint and with so much thought and care obiously put into the making of this DVD, a very small thing indeed.
summary: I may never need to buy another music DVD

reviewText: This is the DVD of the Tour, which includes the CD, Live in Gdansk.  This stop was recorded in London at the Royal Albert Hall and included guest artists, David Bowie and Crosby & Nash of Crosby Stills & Nash fame.  The first half of the concert was the entire album - On an Island, which was David's current release at the time, with the 2nd half of the concert being music from his days as lead guitar & singer song-writer with Pink Floyd.  As I enjoyed this concert so much, I bought both the CD and DVD although they were different stops on the Tour.  Both are rich musicly and I wanted to have these for years to come.  I recommend this - DG is one of the best guitarists around, I believe.  He makes sweet music with his friends.
summary: David Gilmour - Remember that Night - RAH

reviewText: We've come to expect excellence from David Gilmour, and this 2 dvd set delivers in spades. Disc 1 is packed with material from his Royal Albert Hall show, further cementing Dave's reputation as a god of the Stratocaster. He takes turns on lap steel, Hawaiian guitar, saxophone, and something that looks like a cross between a banjo and a cooking pot. In Floydian tradition, the light show is spectacular, and it's so wonderful that he shares the spotlight with Pink keyboardist Richard Wright. For this old Floyd fan, inclusion of a magnificent "Echoes" and Gilmour's "Fat Old Sun" really hit the spot. Guest appearances from David Bowie ("Arnold Layne") and Crosby & Nash are icing on the cake.Disc two continues with a host of stuff too numerous to mention, including out-takes from the concert, another 5 song mini concert, a great video diary of his European tour, the making of "On An Island", two videos, and the previously- available-only-as-a-bonus-track "Island Jam", and more. A fantastic release.

reviewText: I'm going to write a quick "buyer beware" review of this on.1. The content itself is impeccable.  The live Echoes alone is worth the price of admission.  On an Island live is also fantastic.  This is the best live Floyd related release ever.  Better than Pulse.  Better than Roger's DVD.  The music and visuals are that good . . .2. . . . if the disc actually works.  Mine doesn't.  It's not scratched or anything, but it's failed on two DVD players.  It plays just fine till Fat Old Sun.  Then it skips like mad.  Its unable to play most of Fat Old Sun, any of Coming Back to Life, or the first half of High Hopes.  And looking on a few message boards, I'm not the only one with this problem.
summary: Great concert - if the disc actually works . . .

reviewText: this is one of the best music dvds not only this year, but ever.  david is at his best here.  and he just gets better all time.  although roger may have been the 'mind' and driving force behind floyd after syd, david has been the 'sound' of floyd.  this dvd proves that.  and although his solo efforts have always been very, very good, this is the best yet.  it's so sad to see people get old, but it can't be done more gracefully than gilmour is doing it.

reviewText: ...AbsolutelyPositively Stunning!Try not to sit there in complete awe as Gilmour and his band (and a few guests) flawlessly execute the entire ON AN ISLAND album, as well as a goodly portion of PF material that will have you scratching your head and saying to yourself...Hmmm...Waters / Gilmour...Gilmour / Waters...I was a bit skeptical of this offering initially, and having seen Roger Waters and HIS band back in June, I was prepared to accept Gilmour's show as "another" in their little back and forth.But I realize, and happily, that there's more than enough room for the two of them, and you can never get enough great music, no matter who's interpreting it.The full-length ECHOES alone is worth the cost of this package.What does that tell ya?And when rock royalty (Gilmour) invites Rock Royalty (David Bowie) in to participate...you feel a bit privileged just to be a part of the action.A stunning package and a must-have for any David Gilmour or PF fan.One thing that does puzzle me tho' is this...why does he virtually ignore the first two solo records...DAVID GILMOUR and ABOUT FACE?I'd love to hear anything from either of those two albums.BUT.........I ain't complaining...jessaskin'......is all.Enjoy.

reviewText: Wow, over five hours of David Gilmour. I have to say first off that watching this always makes me think of Pink Floyd in Pompeii. At that time David Gilmour bore a striking resemblance to Leonardo Dicaprio, whereas in this he bears a striking resemblance to Malcolm McDowell or Terrence Stamp, but with less hair. He's onstage at the Royal Albert Hall, very much the leader of his band of 10 musicians, many of whom are there to recreate the multiple guitar parts of his Pink Floyd and solo songs. Included from his solo albums are only songs from the recent "On An Island" (nothing from "About Face" or "David Gilmour", for some reason) and he brings David Crosby and Graham Nash to sing harmonies with him. Crosby, Gilmour and Nash sound great, although Crosby and Nash look funny - the former short and paunchy with his hands in his pockets all the time and the latter both boogying and grimacing strainingly as he sings. For a hippy bluesman, it's a bit odd that Gilmour has such a posh accent, but those guitar solos are great, even if he is also a bit paunchy and makes frog faces as he makes his guitar grown and wail. He mostly plays his all-black Stratocaster, although he does pull out a gold Les Paul for a song, and also a flesh-coloured Telecaster, as well as various Turkish string instruments, slide guitars, and at one point a saxophone. Disc 1 is a full concert recording of one of the band's nights at the Royal Albert Hall. Gilmour starts the album with three songs from Dark Side of the Moon - "Speak to Me," "Beathe", they skip "On the Run," then play "Time." It's odd, to me, to not hear the full album (I never listen to single songs from that album if I don't have to) but those three songs sound good, especially the saxophone solo done by Dick Parry, the original performer from Dark Side of the Moon recording - he switches from a baritone sax to a tenor sax without skipping a beat, great stuff. Gilmour and the band then plays the full new album, and it's tight and meaty, with two songs featuring Crosby and Nash, and one with Robert Wyatt of Soft Machine playing the trumpet from his wheelchair. After a break, they come out and play "Shine On Your Crazy Diamond", which for a while is just David Gilmour and Richard Wright behind his impressive bank of keyboards. There is a very nice version of "Fat Old Sun" from the "Atom Heart Mother" album, and also an impressive "Echoes"... which does hearken the listener back to Live At Pompeii... These people have come a long way in 35 years. "Wish You Were Here" feels very personal before it picks up in a band thing. David sings "Find The Cost of Freedom" with Crosby and Nash, one of their songs, before bringing out David Bowie to sing "Arnold Layne" and "Comfortably Numb." It might be hard to imagine Bowie singing Pink Floyd songs, but he does a great great job and makes it sound natural (interesting how I also bought a Bowie CD on the same day, "Live Santa Monica "72'). The solo from "Comfortable Numb" is stunning, especially the lead-out version, which just screams and screams and screams. Dear Lord!!! The crowd were dancing in the aisles, it was terribly moving.But ultimately, while the cameramen do get some nice shots of David soloing and do zoom in on his fingers (one of the main reasons I bought this) the concert suffers a bit from a lack of attention to this point and also some choppy jumping around from player to player, and also an odd "over-the-precipice" camera boom shot that they throw in from time to time that looks like it is the same shot over and over again (you couldnt' tell if it was taken at a different time in the concert, since it was so far from the stage). But this is not a major problem in the video, since there is plenty of everything to please the viewer and the Pink Floyd fan, especially the nuggets and the great guest features.Disc 2 has nice songs on it, as well as some documentaries. For the songs, they do "Arnold Layne" and "Comfortable Numb" with Richard Wright instead of David Bowie from the other nights at the Royal Albert Hall and it's not quite the same - Wright does seem a bit stodgy and square, he clearly has none of Bowie's mojo. Theres also a nice version of "Wot's... Uh, the Deal" from "Obscured by Clouds", one of the nuggets they dug out and a very nice one indeed. Also some Syd Barrett songs "Dominoes" and "Dark Globe." A cool live-in-the-studio verson of "Astronomy Domine," an impromptu rendition of a part of "Echoes." There are five songs performed in the BBC Mermaid Theatre that were part of the first public performance of the album. The video for "On An Island" is very nice, especially the solo which shows David playing in his room of guitars. Smile has background vocals from Polly Sampson, Gilmour's wife, a sweet ballad.There are also some good documentaries, such as 45-minute "Breaking Bread, Drinking Wine" about the "On An Island" tour. They band rehearse in the UK at the same production area that Roger Waters is also renting a part of, so there's a scene of the two having a brief chat and hugging (lots of hugging in this one) and also Nick Mason appearing with David's drummer Steve DiStanislao. Hanging out with Crosby and Nash and Bowie (3D, as in three Davids - Bowie, Crosby and Gilmour), David practising saxophone, and then going on tour. They play a castle in Linz, and David does "Dark Globe," his first performance since Syd Barrett died and the first time he'd ever practiced or performed "Dark Globe." They play at an old Roman amphitheatre in Vienne in France, and of course they reference Pompeii by showing the band doing "Echoes.' They play in the Florence piazza, then also in San Marcos square in Venice where they run into all sorts of logistics problems. There are fun incidents about playing water glasses onstage, and when they run into a street performer who does this in Venice they drag him onstage with them. At the end they meet Lech Walesa and play the shipyards of Gdansk on the 26th anniversary of the Solidarity movement, which is moving. Before the documentary starts a message says "when you see this special mark press enter to see extended content" which means you don't have to hunt around for secret easter eggs to access stuff like this.A 17-minute documentary on the making of "On An Island" is not as good, although you do get a sort of tour of the Astoria, which is Gilmour's houseboat recording studio on the Thames. There are some stories about the inspirations for some of the songs, and tales of how the lyrics got added and why. There's also five minutes of backstage images from the west coast of the US, which are only interesting because Jude Law shows up, and maybe Crispin Hellion Glover (but I'm not so sure if it's him or someone else).

reviewerName: Terrence J. Reardon "Classic rock and old sch...
reviewText: Pink Floyd singer and guitarist David Gilmour just released his new DVD entitled Remember That Night - Live From the Royal Albert Hall and is indeed a MUST for all David Gilmour and Pink Floyd fans.I got the Best Buy version (with a bonus live CD including the AOL Sessions EP) and I have already watched this DVD three times and it is SUPERB! For those who were at The Royal Albert Hall and/or any of his solo shows (I envy you) this is a great souvenir and for those of us who weren't (like me) it shows us what we all missed.There are 23 (technically 25 counting the outro and the intermission) songs on the concert disc of 'Remember That Night', which documents the Royal Albert Hall shows of May 29, 30 and 31, 2006.Gilmour was backed onstage by fellow Floyd member keyboard player Rick Wright, PF 1987 alum which were keyboard player Jon Carin and bass player Guy Pratt, Roxy Music guitarist Phil Manzanera and drummer Steve DiStanislao. Plus, there are guest appearances by David Crosby, Graham Nash (2/3 of Crosby, Stills and Nash and/or 1/2 of Crosby Stills Nash and Young take your pick), Robert Wyatt and the Thin White Duke and rock music's real chameleon David Bowie.The first set begins with three from Dark Side of the Moon which are "Speak to Me", "Breathe", "Time" and "Breathe (Reprise)" (all are excellent versions). Next is the On an Island portion and "Castellorizon" is amazing live, "On An Island" (with Crosby and Nash) is excellent, "The Blue" (with Crosby and Nash) is just awesome live, "Red Sky at Night", "This Heaven", "Then I Close My Eyes" (with Robert Wyatt) is an excellent version, "Smile" is good, "Take A Breath" is excellent live (this track was first released on the OAI CD/DVD set as a taster for the DVD), "A Pocketful of Stones" and an excellent "Where We Start" to finish set one of the first DVD.Next is the intermission film, quite funny.The second set starts with "Shine On You Crazy Diamond" (with Crosby and Nash) then a spirited "Fat Old Sun", "Coming Back To Life", "High Hopes", a spellbinding version of "Echoes", "Wish You Were Here", "Find The Cost Of Freedom" (with Crosby and Nash), a stellar "Arnold Layne" (with David Bowie) and a jawdropping version of "Comfortably Numb" (with David Bowie).The second DVD contains other Royal Albert Hall performances of "Dominoes", "Wots...Uh the Deal", "Wearing the Inside Out" and "Arnold Layne and "Comfortably Numb" (sans Bowie but doesn't include Pink Floyd drummer Nick Mason out of fear of Pink Floyd reunion to boost sales).The second DVD also features three documentaries (one called Breaking Bread Pouring Wine (documenting the tour from March to August of 2006 and there are cameos by Nick and (shock, gasp, horror) Roger Waters who wished David good luck on his second leg and vice versa and seems the feud between them is finally over for good, I remain a swan song from PF is in the cards and Nick Mason and Rick Wright and even Roger Waters want to resurrect PF one last time whilst Gilmour is a bit reluctant to do it at the moment), another documenting DG and company in Los Angeles (funny stuff) and the other is the OAI EPK with some different bits as opposed to the original one on the internet) and pieces from the Mermaid Theater concert from March 7, 2006. Also Island Jam 2007 is included recorded at Gilmour's home in Sussex, England. "Dark Globe" is also included and some Easter Eggs that I cannot give away and you will have to see to find out.This DVD is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
summary: Gilmour's new concert DVD is definitely a MUST OWN
